plyranges
  • Reference
  • Vignettes
    • Introduction to plyranges
    • Using plyranges like bedtools

Group a Ranges by one or more variables

The function group_by takes a Ranges object and defines groups by one or more variables. Operations are then performed on the Ranges by their "group". ungroup() removes grouping.

# S3 method for GRanges
group_by(.data, ...)

# S3 method for GRangesGrouped
ungroup(x, ...)

# S3 method for IRanges
group_by(.data, ...)

# S3 method for IRangesGrouped
ungroup(x, ...)

# S3 method for GRangesGrouped
groups(x)

# S3 method for GRangesGrouped
group_vars(x)

# S3 method for IRangesGrouped
groups(x)

# S3 method for IRangesGrouped
group_vars(x)

# S4 method for GRangesGrouped
show(object)

# S4 method for IRangesGrouped
show(object)

Arguments

.data

a Ranges object.
...

Variable names to group by. These can be either metadata columns or the core variables of a Ranges.
x

a GroupedRanges object.

Details

group_by() creates a new object of class GRangesGrouped if the input is a GRanges object or an object of class IRangesGrouped if the input is a IRanges object. Both of these classes contain a slot called groups corresponding to the names of grouping variables. They also inherit from their parent classes, Ranges and GenomicRanges respectively. ungroup() removes the grouping and will return either a GRanges or IRanges object.

Accessors

To return grouping variables on a grouped Ranges use either

  • groups(x)Returns a list of symbols

  • group_vars(x)Returns a character vector

Examples

set.seed(100)
df <- data.frame(start = 1:10,
                 width = 5,
                 gc = runif(10),
                 cat = sample(letters[1:2], 10, replace = TRUE))
rng <- as_iranges(df)
rng_by_cat <- rng %>% group_by(cat)
# grouping does not change appearance or shape of Ranges
rng_by_cat
#> IRanges object with 10 ranges and 2 metadata columns:
#> Groups: cat
#>            start       end     width |         gc      cat
#>        <integer> <integer> <integer> |  <numeric> <factor>
#>    [1]         1         5         5 | 0.30776611        b
#>    [2]         2         6         5 | 0.25767250        b
#>    [3]         3         7         5 | 0.55232243        a
#>    [4]         4         8         5 | 0.05638315        a
#>    [5]         5         9         5 | 0.46854928        b
#>    [6]         6        10         5 | 0.48377074        b
#>    [7]         7        11         5 | 0.81240262        a
#>    [8]         8        12         5 | 0.37032054        a
#>    [9]         9        13         5 | 0.54655860        a
#>   [10]        10        14         5 | 0.17026205        b
# a list of symbols
groups(rng_by_cat)
#> [[1]]
#> cat
#> 
# ungroup removes any grouping
ungroup(rng_by_cat)
#> IRanges object with 10 ranges and 2 metadata columns:
#>            start       end     width |         gc      cat
#>        <integer> <integer> <integer> |  <numeric> <factor>
#>    [1]         1         5         5 | 0.30776611        b
#>    [2]         2         6         5 | 0.25767250        b
#>    [3]         3         7         5 | 0.55232243        a
#>    [4]         4         8         5 | 0.05638315        a
#>    [5]         5         9         5 | 0.46854928        b
#>    [6]         6        10         5 | 0.48377074        b
#>    [7]         7        11         5 | 0.81240262        a
#>    [8]         8        12         5 | 0.37032054        a
#>    [9]         9        13         5 | 0.54655860        a
#>   [10]        10        14         5 | 0.17026205        b
# group_by works best with other verbs
grng <- as_granges(df,
                   seqnames = "chr1",
                   strand = sample(c("+", "-"), size = 10, replace = TRUE))

grng_by_strand <- grng %>% group_by(strand)
grng_by_strand
#> GRanges object with 10 ranges and 2 metadata columns:
#> Groups: strand
#>        seqnames    ranges strand |         gc      cat
#>           <Rle> <IRanges>  <Rle> |  <numeric> <factor>
#>    [1]     chr1  [ 1,  5]      - | 0.30776611        b
#>    [2]     chr1  [ 2,  6]      - | 0.25767250        b
#>    [3]     chr1  [ 3,  7]      - | 0.55232243        a
#>    [4]     chr1  [ 4,  8]      - | 0.05638315        a
#>    [5]     chr1  [ 5,  9]      + | 0.46854928        b
#>    [6]     chr1  [ 6, 10]      + | 0.48377074        b
#>    [7]     chr1  [ 7, 11]      - | 0.81240262        a
#>    [8]     chr1  [ 8, 12]      - | 0.37032054        a
#>    [9]     chr1  [ 9, 13]      - | 0.54655860        a
#>   [10]     chr1  [10, 14]      + | 0.17026205        b
#>   -------
#>   seqinfo: 1 sequence from an unspecified genome; no seqlengths
# grouping with other verbs
grng_by_strand %>% summarise(gc = mean(gc))
#> DataFrame with 2 rows and 2 columns
#>     strand        gc
#>   <factor> <numeric>
#> 1        + 0.3741940
#> 2        - 0.4147751
grng_by_strand %>% filter(gc == min(gc))
#> GRanges object with 2 ranges and 2 metadata columns:
#> Groups: 
#>       seqnames    ranges strand |         gc      cat
#>          <Rle> <IRanges>  <Rle> |  <numeric> <factor>
#>   [1]     chr1  [10, 14]      + | 0.17026205        b
#>   [2]     chr1  [ 4,  8]      - | 0.05638315        a
#>   -------
#>   seqinfo: 1 sequence from an unspecified genome; no seqlengths
grng_by_strand %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  summarise(gc = mean(gc))
#> DataFrame with 1 row and 1 column
#>          gc
#>   <numeric>
#> 1 0.4026008
